result.execSummary:
This case is being appealed. If the court makes a decision in a case that a party disagrees with, the party may have the right to seek review by a higher court to determine if the trial court's decision was correct. Appeals are most often made after a trial or final decision in a case, but an appeal can also occur before a final decision.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

Motion for an Extension of Time for Filing the Defendant's Notice of Intent to Pursue Postconviction Relief, filed with State of Wisconsin Court of Appeals. (Denied per Order Court of Appeals dated 4/11/17)

Before Reilly, P.J.
The defendant, Roberto J. Juarez Nieves, Jr., moves pro se to extend the time to file a notice of intent to pursue postconviction relief from his convictions of February 6, 2015. It has been over two years since the notice of intent was due. "The longer the extension that is sought, the greater the showing that is generally required to satisfy us that there is good cause for granting it." State v. Quackenbush, 2005 WI App 2, [Par.]11, 278 Wis. 2d 611, 692 N.W.2d 340. We are not persuaded that Juarez Nieves' motion establishes good cause for the requested relief. Therefore,
IT IS ORDERED that the motion to extend the time for filing a notice of intent to pursue postconviction relief is denied.
Clerk's response to the Defendant's pro se Notice of Intent to Pursue Postconviction Relief.

Defendant Roberto J Juarez Nieves in court by video from Milwaukee Secure Detention Facility.  Kevin Michael Osborne appeared for the State of Wisconsin. Court address letters received from the Defendant. State makes statements. Defendant makes statements. Court makes oral ruling. Judgment of Conviction to be amended to reflect change in sentence credit. 50 days sentence credit applies only to Count #23 and is to be removed from Counts 24-28 as they are consecutive count #23 and to each other. Court address letters received from Defendant regarding restitution. Defendant makes statements. Court makes oral ruling, pursuant to 2015 Wisconsin Act 355 amending 301.32(1) of the Wisconsin Statutes, the Department of Corrections now has the authority to use any of your funds to pay victim restitution ordered under 973.20(11)(c) and any other appropriate costs.  Accordingly, the court will take no action concerning the request. State makes statements regarding money that was previously held. Court authorizes money held by US Bank to be released to Waukesha District Attorneys Office and to be used towards restitution. State to draft an order to realease money.

Defendant Roberto J Juarez Nieves in court, in custody, with attorney Christopher Lee Hartley.    District Attorney's Office Law Intern, Becky Van Dam, appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Recommendations by the State.  Statement by victim.  Arguments by the defense.  Statement by defendant.  Defense requests restitution hearing.  Court will give the defense 10 days to work on a stipulation regarding restitution.  If they are unable to come to an agreement a restitution hearing will be set.

Court orders the following:

Count 23:
- Total sentence: 3 years 6 months (Initial Confinement: 1 year 6 months, Extended Supervision: 2 years) STAYED.  Credit for 50 days if revoked.
- 10 years Probation.  Court would approve early termination only if ALL restitution has been paid.
- Court costs waived
- DNA Surcharge waived
- Restitution of $54,933.00 to be paid to N.M. as a Condition of Probation
- Conditions of Probation:   Submit to an AODA assessment and follow through with any treatment/counseling.  Maintain absolute sobriety/Random UAs.  No use or possession of alcohol/drug paraphernalia/drugs without a valid prescription.  Vocational counseling, cognitive intervention, criminal thinking course and/or any other treatment/counseling recommended by Agent.  No contact with victim.  Maintain full-time employment.

Count 24:
- Total sentence: 3 years 6 months (Initial Confinement: 1 year 6 months, Extended Supervision: 2 years) CONSECUTIVE to Count 23.  STAYED.  Credit for 50 days if revoked.
- 10 years Probation.  Court would approve early termination only if ALL restitution has been paid.
- Court costs waived
- DNA Surcharge waived
- Conditions of Probation:   Same as Count 23.

Count 25:
- Total sentence: 3 years 6 months (Initial Confinement: 1 year 6 months, Extended Supervision: 2 years) CONSECUTIVE to Counts 23 and 24.  STAYED.  Credit for 50 days if revoked.
- 10 years Probation.  Court would approve early termination only if ALL restitution has been paid.
- Court costs waived
- DNA Surcharge waived
- Conditions of Probation:   Same as Count 23.

Count 26:
- Total sentence: 3 years 6 months (Initial Confinement: 1 year 6 months, Extended Supervision: 2 years) CONSECUTIVE to Counts 23, 24 and 25.  STAYED.  Credit for 54 days if revoked.
- 10 years Probation.  Court would approve early termination only if ALL restitution has been paid.
- Court costs waived
- DNA Surcharge waived
- Conditions of Probation:   Same as Count 23.

Count 27:
- Total sentence: 3 years 6 months (Initial Confinement: 1 year 6 months, Extended Supervision: 2 years) CONSECUTIVE to Counts 23, 24, 25 and 26.  STAYED.
- 10 years Probation.  Court would approve early termination only if ALL restitution has been paid.
- Court costs waived
- DNA Surcharge waived
- Conditions of Probation:   Same as Count 23.

Count 28:
- Total sentence: 3 years 6 months (Initial Confinement: 1 year 6 months, Extended Supervision: 2 years) CONSECUTIVE to Counts 23, 24, 25, 26 and 27.  STAYED.
